article_title: Pricier health plans more popular off ACA exchanges
article_text:
Pricier health plans more popular off ACA exchanges

Photo: San Antonio Express-News /File Photo U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services Sylvia Burwell, center,...

Shoppers buying health insurance from traditional sources have shown a greater affinity for pricier gold and platinum plans than have consumers seeking tax credits through federal and state venues, a report shows.

article_metadata.description: Shoppers buying health insurance from traditional sources have shown a greater affinity for pricier gold and platinum plans than have consumers seeking tax credits through federal and state venues, a report shows.  The more expensive gold and platinum plans — which offer more generous benefits and cover a greater share of beneficiaries’ medical costs — also appeal to people who have health problems or a family member with a medical condition, the report noted.  “If a client is ill or they’ve got a family member who has a prolonged illness or has some medical problems, that’s where we really dig in and put a pencil to the gold and platinum plans that are available,” said independent insurance agent Justin Holland, founder and owner of Texas State Financial & Health, a San Antonio firm.  Both Camp and Holland are members of the San Antonio Association of Health Underwriters, a group of licensed independent health insurance agents, brokers and benefits consultants.  “Narrow networks are less appealing ... to people with more complex health problems who tend to prefer a wider choice of specialists,” the report stated.  [...] people with pre-existing conditions could be more likely to shop for plans off the exchanges.  The Commonwealth Fund report released Aug. 18 showed that 570 insurers nationwide had projected in their filings with the federal government that more than 11 million people would buy health insurance this year on the government-run exchanges, while a smaller number of customers — nearly 3 million people — would buy health plans outside of the federal and state marketplaces.  [...] they predicted only 37 percent of consumers buying health insurance outside of those exchanges would select silver plans, compared to 58 percent of customers shopping in government-run markets.
article_metadata.author.name: By Peggy O’Hare, Staff Writer

Both Camp and Holland are members of the San Antonio Association of Health Underwriters, a group of licensed independent health insurance agents, brokers and benefits consultants.  “Narrow networks are less appealing ... to people with more complex health problems who tend to prefer a wider choice of specialists,” the report stated.  [...] people with pre-existing conditions could be more likely to shop for plans off the exchanges.  The Commonwealth Fund report released Aug. 18 showed that 570 insurers nationwide had projected in their filings with the federal government that more than 11 million people would buy health insurance this year on the government-run exchanges, while a smaller number of customers — nearly 3 million people — would buy health plans outside of the federal and state marketplaces.  [...] they predicted only 37 percent of consumers buying health insurance outside of those exchanges would select silver plans, compared to 58 percent of customers shopping in government-run markets.
